node.title: ‘Back to the Outback’ Review: Pest in Show
node.alt: From left, Doug (voiced by Keith Urban), Pretty Boy (Tim Minchin) and Doreen (Gia Carides) in “Back to the Outback.”
node.description: A group of reptile house critters escape from an Australian zoo in this endearing animated adventure.
node.content: ["An animated zoological romp about animals escaping Australian captivity, \u201cBack to the Outback\u201d plays, in many ways, like Netflix\u2019s response to \u201cMadagascar.\u201d Forget zebras and giraffes cavorting outdoors: Here, our heroes are smaller, grosser creatures confined in glass vivariums. Reptiles, arachnids and amphibians, oh my!", "When the story begins, the venomous taipan Maddie (voiced by Isla Fisher) is crestfallen to find that zoo visitors recoil from her. She finds little solace in Chaz (Eric Bana), her macho handler who encourages onlookers to treat Maddie and her cast of invertebrate mates as dangerous gross-outs. A gentle creature, Maddie feels betrayed; she and her friends are coldblooded, but they\u2019re warmhearted.", "Alongside her pals \u2014 including a lizard (Miranda Tapsell) and hairy spider (Guy Pearce) \u2014 Maddie hatches a plot to escape cruel captivity and journey to the outback where, she hopes, compassionate kin await. The zoo\u2019s resident Narcissus, a cuddly but pampered koala named Pretty Boy (Tim Minchin), unexpectedly joins the adventure.", "Directed by Clare Knight and Harry Cripps, \u201cBack to the Outback\u201d falls in a tradition of animated movies about the animal kingdom; the far superior film \u201cFinding Nemo\u201d even shared Australia as a setting. But however generic this movie is in premise, there is wit to be found in its details, and warmth in its message. Its cleverest running gag concerns the Ugly Secret Society, a faction of resourceful misfits who vow to protect fellow \u201cugly\u201d critters \u2014 a deus ex machina that, like \u201cBack to the Outback\u201d as a whole, is unexpectedly touching."]
